strategically one of the um one of the let's just go back to looking at a basic
idea of what is strategy you know this is a strategic thinking equation sort of a classic equation out of most um
strategy books Michael Porter and and folks from The Business Schools there's a very simple equation that says value
creation coming up with ideas plus value capture learning how to you know move those ideas to markets effectively
equals a strategy a competitive sustainable Advantage if you can do this better than your competitors you have a
strong uh strategic position well if you look at what I just talked about the just in time re-engineering Six Sigma uh
techniques these are all about value capture assuming you got a great idea how do you take it to the market
efficiently how do you manufacture at a lower cost how do you segment your markets and address uh key um uh market
shares in a way that gives you an advantage but assuming everybody has already done that or assuming that you
you've got processes in place and you're looking for an additional boost to your strategic um
portfolio people are starting to say okay where are those good good ideas
coming from where is that radical Apple tablet in our product mix or where is that Financial uh uh product that nobody
else has how are we coming up with these ideas and so they're starting to look at Value creation and that's where design
comes into play because it's really the one business discipline and it is a discipline if practiced properly where
the sole concern is increasing the value of the firm through creativity and
Innovation uh and finding those you know white spaces in the market and design
thinking which is just using the tools that designers have perfected for inventing products and services that
those same tools can be applied to strategic thinking and we believe if they become a
COR competency of the company um then the company is uh more immune to the
rapidly changing markets and aggressive competitors because they are out creating them on the value side of this
equation other thing is there's sort of a design thinking twist to this equation value creation value capture we really
talk about that as problem finding and problem solving I want you to just think back to the last five or six projects
you worked on in your organization and how much of the time did you spend on just solving a problem somebody's you
know uh you got a market share problem you've got a manufacturing issue you've got a cost issue maybe you've got uh a
competitive strategy issue most people spend all of their time assuming that the problem they've been given is the
correct one and trying to solve it but there's a really a lot of Leverage in
this process comes from looking at the problem finding part there's an old adage of problem well defined as half
salt and what we find is that most people uh get an enormous amount of Leverage by moving up the food chain in
this equation and really looking at the problem finding aspects of design
thinking so to to make it a little more explicit design thinking is a method of
finding good problems before it's anything else it's about looking at what are you actually uh trying to solve and
not working on symptoms but working on core root problems and then it's a method of framing Solutions so that they
have uh a wider application and can be more Innovative and forming those Solutions in a way that's different from
the traditional methods using analytic or deductive reasoning design thinking relies more on
synthesis and it REM relies more on the ideas that you find and the context in
which you find them so it's a not a data reduction technique it's actually a method of putting things together rather
than breaking them apart it employs creativity and many many tools to enhance the number of ideas that you're
choosing from it employs empathy which is an interesting Concept in of itself and uh the next webinar we'll go into
that more deeply but but basically empathy is a sort of a deep dive into what the you know the the context of the
problem is really really all about we use prototyping and lots of iteration we're multi-disciplinary by by
definition and it requires a form of um teamwork which we call radical
collaboration and it's particularly powerful when you're dealing with the kinds of problems that I think most people are dealing with nowadays in
their organizations problems that are defined as I would say poorly bounded if you're using engineering term or if you
use the term a wicked problem that's a an idea that came out of some guys at Berkeley a while back which you know
problems that just are messy you really can't just find all the constituents who uh interact with the problem as you try
to solve the problem more constituents become visible um these are the sorts of
problems where there isn't a right or wrong answer but there's a better and worse answer and most strategic problems
fit this category and the problem we see more often than not is people trying to
use analytic techniques which assumes you could know all the boundary conditions you could know all the inputs
and then and then rationally you could solve the problem they try to use those techniques and problems that just don't yield to that
kind of an approach and since designers kind of do this magical thing where they invent something out of nothing they're
quite comfortable uh with problems that have uh bad boundary conditions and no right
or wrong answer um nobody can tell you that they want uh an iPod or an iPhone
they uh they can only tell you they want one after they've seen one so how do you get to the thing when you don't know
what it is that people want well that's the techniques that designers use to invent products and you can use the same
techniques for uh strategy um we've been doing this for a while um just a little a little
commercial here for for the Stanford gang uh you know about 50 years ago 1963 we put together a program which was
crazy in its day it was you know Engineers talking to artists and and psychologists and uh and you know uh
looking at how creativity really starts um uh We've started this new dchool thing
which is sort of at the Forefront of a Trends to blend design and thinking and strategy uh business and human you know
human factors human values and David Kelly who's the founder of the D school and also one of the core um senior
professor in our program and the guy who started founded Ido the the company I

be great design thinkers and we think there's not only design thinkers obviously you're not going to throw away your rational and and uh business
methods for um managing uh large organizations but if you add in design
thinking you've got an extra strategic uh weapon what it also is is really a
dynamic approach to problem solving we still do a lot of problem solving in design uh it works particularly on these
poorly bounded problems we use prototyping and I'll show you a sort of a process diagram in a second it'll
it'll kind of make that more explicit um and we use prototyping in a couple ways one is just um to uh do rapid learning
and Improvement um you've probably heard the expression you know fail early fail often we like to we like to do a lot of
that in fact it's a really it's more of a fail early to succeed sooner kind of strategy but it recognizes um that uh
when you don't have all the answers uh you build to think you don't try to rationalize your way through the problem
you buil to think it's also you know as I mentioned an approach to problem finding the highest leverage we find in
most of these strategic conundrums or dilemmas is really stepping back and trying to reframe um the issue and in
that reframing and using the tools I'll show you one in a second um you often
avoid the sort of solving symptoms uh and uh looking at uh finding the real
true latent issues or latent needs inside a problem I also think that this
creates kind of A New Perspective it changes the way organizations look at Value creation because it's a human-
centered perspective at the basis of all strategic problems or Market problems or product problems there's a human being
somewhere um and if you involve the human being in a human- centered co-creation process and you focus on the
actual uh real needs and not the symptoms you create a different value for all the stakeholders in the
organization and you get a tremendous buyin um from your customers your
suppliers um and other people in the value chain so I mentioned we have a process
everybody's got a little process diagram it wouldn't be a PowerPoint presentation if you didn't have some boxes with
arrows um here's one it's and it's pretty fairly simple right we start with uh observation depending on what the
problem is depending on whether we're looking at a business issue a strategic issue product issue um product line
issue uh new competitors entering the market um I was at CES a couple of weeks
ago there's about 15 companies who have introduced tablet computers desperately hoping to get some kind of buzz going uh
and in fact it's all going to start tomorrow when when um Apple introduces

start with observation you know you say what is actually the you know the Laten need the root cause of what's going on
here your information will be incomplete so instead of trying to analyze further you build something you
build a prototype you do a quick evaluation back with users and with the
with the Design Group on what that what that prototype means and then you do it again in iteration is a box here in this
process diagram to make sure that you understand repetition is is critical to the process
you're going to collapse the boundary conditions you're going to find out more about the process by moving through a
set of iterative prototypes eventually you create some output now that's that
in of itself is not particularly um a radical notion uh but it occurs in a
context it occurs in a context of radical collaboration um if you're let's say
you're trying to design a new Financial Service um if you're City actually a
service that was designed U by our um uh our friends at Ido many of our ex-
students are now Ido employees was the change back program um where uh you
charge something on a um a credit card and they round it up to the nearest number and then you end up saving that
amount of money so you can design a service this way you can design a product this way you can design a strategy this way but it requires
getting outside of the group think of one part of your organization you know I'm here at Stanford University
universities you can't find a more siloed um place than universities there's the you know department of
engineering is different than the department of of computer science which is different than the department of humanities and on and on and on and we
live in these little silos but we've managed to find ways to break those silos down and and have computer
scientists talking to psychologists talking to uh cultural
anthropologists working with designers to create projects U that are exciting and different um radical collaboration
is the process that we employ to make this design um iteration work if you
bring in people from completely different points of view on the problem
you're going to end up with a much richer set of solutions but even then you need one more thing and that's you
need to train that team just throwing experts from different um disciplines together on some kind of a task force uh
often just results in people um hardening their own ideas and their own
points of view and then uh arguing from those points of view what you need to do is train the team in two things what we
call fluency and flexibility now flexibility is about having many many problem solving um strategies available
to you uh the old the old um expression when all you've got is a hammer every
problem looks like a nail is even more true when you have a radical collaboration uh you've got a
psychologist who only wants to do testing you've got an engineer who only wants to do equations you've got a um a
cultural Anthropologist who just wants to do field work so you've got to you got to get these people actually
together working with common tools and with lots and lots of problem solving techniques and we teach lots of these
you probably do brainstorming in your organizations you might do idea mapping we also to do morphological analysis
analogic thinking biomimicry we have lots and lots of ways of stimulating um
new new tools and and a big bag of tools so that people don't get stuck so flexibility is having many many tools
many problem solving techniques uh that the team has been trained on influency is the ease with which they use any one
of these tools and how quickly they can move back and forth so the context the
two context dependent variables to make to make the process work is you got to have radical collaboration between
people who are experts in their different fields but you've got to train them to be flexible and fluent and then
you run them through a process of observation build to think and you end up with you know finally an output of a
form of a service a product a strategy a thing form giving in this case it's just
the final details of how the thing is implemented so that's a that's a that's
sort of the in a in a very quick summary the way that this design thinking sort
of process works let me show you one of the Frameworks that we use a lot um and it's really an innovation we call it I
call it an Innovations framework and it's a sort of classic uh Little 2 by two you've got two axes the now whatever
you're making now your current offerings your current strategy in the future where you'd like to find new opportunities and you've got the
concrete on the vertical axis into the abstract and what we find uh is that
most uh teams are kind of stuck in the Box everybody talks about you know out of the box thinking well what is the Box
the box is really just sitting down in the concrete now we've got a current product or service we've got a current
uh tactic or strategy that we're using it's uh it's not working well or we want to change it and so we are down in the
concrete now and we're dealing with the tyranny of the immediate over the um the
issues that we really should be thinking about and we get stuck doing iterative
problems solving and we come up with one or two ideas that are a little bit
better than what we had but they certainly aren't groundbreaking or brand new and uh and it's pretty common to be
in this situation there's an awful lot of um as I said the tyranny of the immediate lots of Demands uh quarterly
earnings uh uh resource shortages all the things we talked about in the very first slide so people get stuck down in
the Box we'd suggest that you really want to have at all four quadrants of this
diagram and and what you should be doing rather than trying to invent in the concrete now is just do observation
observe clearly about what the issue of problem well defined is half solve if you take your observations and you move
up up into the uh abstract um but still current now you
say okay what I mean when I really look at these observations what does that mean what kind of insights can I get
from that what sort of synthesis can I do with that and then when you move from
that quadrant into the quadrant to the abstract um future and you go abstract
future first you're saying you're actually asking yourself the question given those insights what's the best
possible future product uh future outcome that I can predict so I take my
insights and I I'm just I just forc myself to conceptualize those insights in the
future and then I drop down into the future now which is really the white space the blue ocean place that I want
to be and that's where I come up with lots and lots of New Opportunities and let me give you it's a little bit of an
abstract idea so let me give you a very simple um description this one is happens to be a product that one of our
a product idea that one of our students has and it's got a wonderful outcome so I can use it as an example but it's

their check tailor and so you could have just said I'm going to do you know if there's white and black shoelaces I'm

concrete now to the concrete now but what he did instead was step back and say um I'm not just going to look at

just kind of a fashion statement and in fact the the The Innovation is all in
how they express themselves through the way they um the shoes are tied and the customers are doing The Innovation
they're finding ways to tie shoes in a different way and you also notice that most of the really interesting stuff the
real cool Trends were coming out of uh inner city um high schools where the
kids were inventing new ways to wear their shoes as a means of expressing something something about themselves so
we zoomed that observation into the future and came up with a framework and some design principles that says one
fashion emerges in the inner city two it's all about attitude it's all about
um context and three uh that the game the name of the game is fastening the
name of the game is not um shoelace per se dropped that down and uh did a

it is not a velcro it is something completely different um license just
just signed a licensing deal with Converse which is why I'm telling this story um to launch this uh a new product
